children.subject: Same thing. Lecture and discussion are treated the same by the enrollment system.
Then what is the point of keeping more seats in either one. Why not keep them the same?

This has been asked and answered on Piazza previously. We often like to give students a bit more flexibility to switch around in secondary sections. If the number of seats in lab and discussion equaled the number of seats in lecture, it wouldn't be as easy to switch. It should be that the number of seats in the secondary sections are greater than the number of seats in the lecture. If it's the reverse, that might be an error as we don't want to give false hope that there are more seats than there are actually are.

I'm sorry if this is a repeated question, but since some policies have changed, I don't know what is up to date. There are courses where the number of discussion seats are greater than the lecture seats, e.g. CS 160 has 134 discussion seats and 120 lecture seats. Also, what you mentioned does not apply to most upper division CS courses now, since everyone is placed into the 999 discussion. So flexibility isn't an issue anymore for those courses.

I understand that discussion seat numbers and lecture seat numbers are independent of each other due to factors such as TA hiring, webcasted lectures, etc., so it makes sense for one to have more seats than the other. But, it's hard for students to judge which classes they will get into and which they won't.

Unfortunately our department schedulers are really busy trying to help students enroll at this time of the semester. I think it's unlikely they'll be able to get back to you with an explanation. This is their job and I trust that their decisions are intentional and intended to best serve students.

The post mentions that, "As long as you are wait listed at the 'lower level' you will remain on the wait list for the lecture.". What about the opposite, where there are more seats allocated to discussion than lecture. What happens in this situation? For example, suppose Class X has 100 lecture seats, but has 120 discussion seats. What happens in this situation?
Also having the same issue: I was at position 51 with 49 open seats listed as of a few days ago, and am now at position 24 with 15 open seats listed, with no time conflicts.
It looks like the class only expanded by 25 seats, not 40 seats, and there are no current open seats. In which case, both of you went up in the waitlist by a reasonable number of spots.

I was on the waitlist for CS 160 at position 34 and noticed from another post @4823 that there were 40 seats released and recently filled. Even though I am pretty sure I don't have a "problem" as described here, I only moved up to position 9. Could there be another reason for this?

Hi All,

I've been getting some questions from CS61B students who were told to drop & re-enroll in sections that have open space to get into the class. If you choose to do that, MAKE SURE THERE ARE OPEN SEATS IN THE LECTURE before you do this. Otherwise you get bumped further down the wait list until people drop & space becomes available in the lecture!
All conflicts.

About class overridden

My intended CS 61C lab overlaps with Math 53 discussion. Should I submit the form above? Thanks!
It should not; this is part of what the Swap feature is designed to do.

I am trying to enroll in EE16A. Is it considered a "problem" if I am enrolled in 188 as of now, but I "swapped" 188 with EE16A (same lecture time).

I am waitlisted for EE16A, and it is my understanding that I will be dropped from 188 if I get off the waitlist for EE16A.

Will the system still consider this a time conflict?

Thank you
I will process this list again tomorrow (Monday)

Could you please tell us the next day when the time conflict forms are processed? So after the day, we would know that "I am not moved into the class, and need to resubmit the form to indicate that I still need help." ?

Thanks!

I have a time conflict now with CS61C and my math course lecture.  Currently there are no combinations of open lab/ open discussion that I see.  I have filled out the form with requests to be placed in labs/discussions I do not have conflicts with.  I thought this was less risky than re-enrolling into labs/discussions I know are full.  Was this the correct process to take?

Also, it seems I am going up on the waitlist as well (from 15 to 17) You explained briefly in the comments but I don't think that applies to my situation.
There's no space in the class, so submitting the form wouldn't do anything.

Actually that's not true. If a space opens up & I can enroll you, I will. If not, I purge you from the list created by the form.

Re-submit the form every 3 days as long as you want me to attempt to enroll you in the class. That's how I know you're still interested in getting into the class.
When (what days) exactly should we know to re-submit the form? Thanks!

I have submitted the time conflict forms 5 days ago but it seems that I'm still not enrolled in the class.

Specifically, I was on the 1st place of waitlist for CS 168 5 days ago, and right now I'm still on the 1st place of waitlist.

Depends on the course, and on your position on the waitlist. Students will be dropping up until the end of the 5th week of course.

You can see @3297 that some courses stopped letting students off the waitlist a bit before then last semester.
when do we typically find out if we'll get off of the waitlist?
If you've reached your unit cap, we will not be able to enroll you
Yes, of course. But could you please answer my first question? Are the SIS form and this google form both required? Or only this google form will do? Thanks!

In another post @3899 it says that we need to submit the SIS form before submitting this one. But in this post it looks like we should submit this google form INSTEAD of the SIS one?

I currently have reached my unit cap and I can't pull up another SIS time conflict form by creating a time conflict (trying to enroll in a conflicted class). So I wonder is submitting the google form here good enough?

Thanks!
Looks like you're enrolled.

I was number 1 on the waitlist for 186 and have dropped to 3 then back to 2. I keep on shifting, but not getting into the class, even though there's available seats. I know I don't have a time conflict, but not sure what to do.
See follow-up in @4869

I notice that most of the 186 waitlist has been processed, so what about the 286 waitlist? It seems that 286 only has 20 seats and has already been filled up but 186 still has open seats even after all the people on the waitlist get off. Can someone tell us how the grad waitlist will be processed? Thanks
Yes. (Although it looks like there's been 8 open seats in the class since the afternoon, so it seems possible that many, if not all, of the people on the waitlist have conflicts.)
I forgot to submit this form before CS170 expanded the class - is the only chance I have now when someone drops the course? :(

If the form was processed, you would be in the class.

But the form can't get processed if there's no open space in the class.

Although there's more open space in the class right now then there are people on the waitlist.
Why wasn't the form processed before...? Are people without conflicts prioritised?
See above about discussion of why the form can't be processed if there is no open space in the class.

How do you know if the form has been processed or not? I'm number 3 in 70 but only moved up that much from 10 originally. I had submitted the conflict form twice before, so I don't know if it was ever received at this point.

Yes, conflict forms are still being processed every 3 days. I did it this morning & will process it again on Friday morning.

It is okay to leave the LAB section blank for 999 classes.

Two questions:

1. Are conflict forms still being processed?

2. When filling out the conflict form, if the class I want only has a 999 discussion section, is it okay to leave the LAB section empty and fill out 999 for discussion?
See the post for instructions?
I did fill up the conflict form last week and it is still not processed.
Yes, and the post addresses why that happens and what to do in that scenario.
I filled up the form last Friday however I'm still on waitlist... what should I do?

history.content:
I've had a large number of questions about how the wait list processes so I thought I'd give you a general explanation of how the enrollment system works. This will be true for any class - not just EECS classes.

Right now the system is processing the wait list 4 times a day (that should continue until the 3rd week of classes or so). It runs at 12:30am, 6:30am, 12:30pm, and 6:30pm.

The system processes the wait list in numerical order starting at position 1 and continuing on. NO PRIORITY IS GIVEN FOR EECS OR CS MAJORS on the wait list. (Priority was given during phase 1 & phase 2 but has ended now that the adjustment period has begun.)

When the system encounters a 'problem' with a student on the wait list, it leaves the student on the wait list and moves to the next person on the list.


What's considered a 'problem':

  • Being wait listed for a lab and/or discussion section. As long as you are wait listed at the 'lower level' you will remain on the wait list for the lecture. To remedy this situation, you will need to drop from the class and re-enroll into section(s) that have space.

           Note: Be sure to select section(s) with more than 1 or 2 open seats of possible. Remember, others are also trying this trick and the section may fill up before your request is processed. This will result in you being bumped to the end of the wait list. In that case, no one can move you back to your original spot on the wait list.
  • Having a time conflict with another class will keep you on the wait list. To request help resolving time conflicts for CS classes you need to fill out a different form that the one indicated in Campus Solutions. Use this form instead:  https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1y8X4t_os_plqKtH0hu7xbqW1Iotn-zjcPJ_tJBu_ttQ/edit 

          Note: Time conflict forms are processed every 3 days. As many students are moved into the class as space allows. If you are not moved into the class, you need to resubmit the form to indicate that you still need help.

Last notes:

  • Unless you have a time conflict, the system will AUTOMATICALLY enroll you into the class when/if space becomes available.
     
  • Please do not contact me asking what the odds are of you getting into a class. Much as I would love to reassure you, I am working on hundreds of enrollments and do not have time to respond individually to these questions. Others on Piazza may be able to give you some ideas but frankly, it is ALWAYS a good idea to have a back up plan just in case.
  • Check other pinned posts for updates about class expansions that may be in the works.
